qas.question: What is the Latin term for insect?
Who introduced the Latin term for insect, borrowing from the Greek vernacular?
How many sections does an insect's body appear to be divided?
Which Greek philosopher used the term entomos to describe insects, making reference to their notched bodies?
In what year is it typically reported that the word insect was first documented in English?
Insect means to have a notched or divided what?
Insects are cut into how many sections?
Who gave this class of life the name "insect"?
In what year did the word "insect" appear in a document?
Who introduced the Latin version of the word "insect"?

context: The word "insect" comes from the Latin word <a0_0>insectum<a0_0/>, meaning "with a notched or divided <a5_0>body<a5_0/>", or literally "cut into", from the neuter singular perfect passive participle of insectare, "to cut into, to cut up", from in- "into" and secare "to cut"; because insects appear "cut into" <a2_0><a6_0>three<a2_0/> sections<a6_0/>. <a1_0><a9_0>Pliny the Elder<a9_0/><a1_0/> introduced the Latin designation as a loan-translation of the Greek word ἔντομος (éntomos) or "insect" (as in entomology), which was <a7_0>Aristotle<a7_0/>'s term for this class of life, also in reference to their "notched" bodies. "Insect" first appears documented in English in <a4_0><a8_0>1601<a8_0/><a4_0/> in Holland's translation of Pliny. Translations of <a3_0>Aristotle<a3_0/>'s term also form the usual word for "insect" in Welsh (trychfil, from trychu "to cut" and mil, "animal"), Serbo-Croatian (zareznik, from rezati, "to cut"), Russian (насекомое nasekomoje, from seč'/-sekat', "to cut"), etc.
